unnormalised: The Delhi Jal Board (DJB) has announced revised water tariff rates, effective from 01/07/2024. The adjustments are purportedly aimed at addressing the mounting operational costs and ensuring equitable distribution across the city. Consumers can expect to see the changes reflected in their August bills.
normalised: The Delhi J-A-L Board (D-J-B) has announced revised water tariff rates, effective from first July two thousand and twenty four. The adjustments are purportedly aimed at addressing the mounting operational costs and ensuring equitable distribution across the city. Consumers can expect to see the changes reflected in their August bills.

unnormalised: According to official sources, households consuming up to 20,000 liters of water per month will continue to receive a subsidy, paying only a nominal charge. However, consumption exceeding this threshold will attract a revised rate of ₹5 per 1,000 liters for the first 10,000 liters above the limit. Subsequent consumption will be charged at an incrementally higher rate, reaching ₹10 per 1,000 liters for usage exceeding 40,000 liters.
normalised: According to official sources, households consuming up to twenty thousand liters of water per month will continue to receive a subsidy, paying only a nominal charge. However, consumption exceeding this threshold will attract a revised rate of rupee five per one thousand liters for the first ten thousand liters above the limit. Subsequent consumption will be charged at an incrementally higher rate, reaching rupee ten per one thousand liters for usage exceeding forty thousand liters.

unnormalised: The electricity consumption for July also saw a marked increase, attributed to the prolonged heatwave. Average households recorded a consumption of 500 units, compared to 350 units in June. BSES Yamuna Power Limited (BYPL) reported a peak demand of 7695 MW on 15/07/2024.
normalised: The electricity consumption for July also saw a marked increase, attributed to the prolonged heatwave. Average households recorded a consumption of five hundred units, compared to three hundred and fifty units in June. B-S-E-S Yamuna Power Limited (B-Y-P-L) reported a peak demand of seven thousand six hundred and ninety five M-W on fifteenth July two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: Further, the Delhi government is also considering implementing smart metering systems to improve billing accuracy and monitor consumption patterns in real-time. A pilot project is scheduled to commence in Dwarka Sector-10 on 01/10/2024, involving the installation of 5000 smart meters. The project aims to reduce AT&C losses, which currently stand at 18%.
normalised: Further, the Delhi government is also considering implementing smart metering systems to improve billing accuracy and monitor consumption patterns in real-time. A pilot project is scheduled to commence in Dwarka Sector-ten on first October two thousand and twenty four, involving the installation of five thousand smart meters. The project aims to reduce A-T and C losses, which currently stand at eighteen percent.

unnormalised: Consumers are advised to regularly monitor their water and electricity consumption and adopt conservation measures to mitigate the impact of the tariff revisions. The DJB and discoms have launched public awareness campaigns, disseminating tips on water harvesting and energy-efficient practices through print and digital media.
normalised: Consumers are advised to regularly monitor their water and electricity consumption and adopt conservation measures to mitigate the impact of the tariff revisions. The D-J-B and discoms have launched public awareness campaigns, disseminating tips on water harvesting and energy-efficient practices through print and digital media.
